p: On the issue of discourse, we argue that labels such as ‘climate refugees’ further reinforces a disempowering vulnerability narrative that permits governmental agencies to ‘act upon’ people rather than ‘act with them’ to mitigate current and future climatic risk. Whereas what is needed is a transformative resilience-based discourse that fosters the self-determination of communities and the agency of individuals in decision making, planning, and implementation, – as seen in the case of New York residents after Hurricane Sandy (Baker et al., 2018). Although, this example also suggests that the socio-economic status of affected populations, the lack of information and communication, and the persuasiveness of local mitigation officials, – can influence the acceptance of retreat, thereby undermining people’s agency (De Vries and Fraser, 2012, Baker et al., 2018).
